ALL.source: Generic ketogenic diet definition commonly limits carbohydrate to ~≤30 g/day to promote ketosis (e.g., Volek & Phinney; clinical keto practice).
Keto consensus places protein as moderate (~15–25% of total energy) to preserve lean mass while maintaining ketosis.
Keto consensus provides most energy from fat (~70–80% of total energy).
Keto diets increase sodium losses; clinical keto practice and Phinney & Volek recommend ~3–5 g/day sodium.
Adequate potassium is emphasized in ketogenic diets (~3–4.7 g/day) to support electrolyte balance and muscle function.
Magnesium is commonly supplemented in keto diets (300–500 mg/day) to prevent cramps and support energy metabolism.
Therapeutic ketogenic protocols (e.g., clinical epilepsy programs) commonly use ~≤20 g/day carbohydrate to initiate/maintain ketosis.
